elements.content: The joining of bimetallic trinuclear nodes, [(CuL1)2Cd] (where H2L1 = N,N′-bis(α-methylsalicylidene)-1,3-propanediamine) by a spacer, 4,4′-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2L2), produced two isomeric one-dimensional coordination polymers, having molecular formula {[(CuL1)2CdL2]·H2O} n . Structural characterization revealed that, in complex 1, one of the oxygen atoms of each carboxylate group of the linker [L2]2– coordinates only to the central Cd­(II) atom of the node in η1 fashion. However, in complex 2, both the oxygen atoms of each carboxylate group coordinate to the metal centers, one to Cd­(II) and the other to a terminal Cu­(II) via η2 syn–syn bridging mode. Moreover, the two bridging carboxylate O atoms are mutually cis in 1 while these are trans in 2. These differences resulted in the novel isomeric zigzag (or cis) and linear (or trans) chains of the coordination polymer. DFT calculations revealed that complex 2 is thermodynamically more stable than complex 1 by 4.3 kcal/mol in the gas phase. The electrical characterizations, i.e., impedance, capacitance, and current–voltage (I–V) studies, reveal substantive electrical conductivity for both complexes, but the charge transport properties are higher for 2 in comparison to 1. Both the materials exhibit photoswitching properties as they show increased electrical conductivity under illuminated conditions than under dark conditions. However, complex 2 shows significantly higher photosensitivity (P S = 571.50) compared to 1 (P S = 201.40) and thus has more potentiality toward fabrication of photosensitive devices.
elements.clean_text: The joining of bimetallic trinuclear nodes, [(CuL1)2Cd] (where H2L1 = N,N'-bis(α-methylsalicylidene)-1,3-propanediamine) by a spacer, 4,4'-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2L2), produced two isomeric one-dimensional coordination polymers, having molecular formula {[(CuL1)2CdL2]⋅H2O} n . Structural characterization revealed that, in complex 1, one of the oxygen atoms of each carboxylate group of the linker [L2]2- coordinates only to the central Cd(II) atom of the node in η1 fashion. However, in complex 2, both the oxygen atoms of each carboxylate group coordinate to the metal centers, one to Cd(II) and the other to a terminal Cu(II) via η2 syn-syn bridging mode. Moreover, the two bridging carboxylate O atoms are mutually cis in 1 while these are trans in 2. These differences resulted in the novel isomeric zigzag (or cis) and linear (or trans) chains of the coordination polymer. DFT calculations revealed that complex 2 is thermodynamically more stable than complex 1 by 4.3 kcal/mol in the gas phase. The electrical characterizations, i.e., impedance, capacitance, and current-voltage (I-V) studies, reveal substantive electrical conductivity for both complexes, but the charge transport properties are higher for 2 in comparison to 1. Both the materials exhibit photoswitching properties as they show increased electrical conductivity under illuminated conditions than under dark conditions. However, complex 2 shows significantly higher photosensitivity (P S = 571.50) compared to 1 (P S = 201.40) and thus has more potentiality toward fabrication of photosensitive devices.

elements.content: Two new isomeric coordination polymers have been synthesized by joining (CuL)2Cd units with 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate linkers. Trans isomer is much more active toward electrical conductivity and photoswitching than cis isomer.
elements.clean_text: Two new isomeric coordination polymers have been synthesized by joining (CuL)2Cd units with 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate linkers. Trans isomer is much more active toward electrical conductivity and photoswitching than cis isomer.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on the Structure Property Relationship in Crystalline Solids

Introduction

The synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) has been increasingly drawing attention in the fields of coordination chemistry and crystal engineering. This is not only because of their diverse structures and topologies but also because of their wide applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, drug delivery, and sensing applications. However, until now, the tailored synthesis of CPs has remained rather challenging because certain external factors, like temperature, solubility, molecularity, solvent systems, pH values, crystallization processes, etc., have a profound effect on the final structure of the CPs. On the other hand, a judicious variation of these factors can produce different isomeric CPs from the same reactants. The isolation of different isomers is very important as they provide an unparalleled means for the understanding of structure–property relationships. A notable example is the isolation of cis-platin, cis-[Pt­(NH3)2C12], which is widely used in cancer chemotherapy, whereas trans-platin exhibits no antitumor activity at all. However, to perceive the isomeric effect, most of the work has been done with discrete mono- or polynuclear species; not much work is reported on isomerism of coordination polymers and on the differences in their properties.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on the Structure Property Relationship in Crystalline Solids

Introduction

The synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) has been increasingly drawing attention in the fields of coordination chemistry and crystal engineering. This is not only because of their diverse structures and topologies but also because of their wide applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, drug delivery, and sensing applications. However, until now, the tailored synthesis of CPs has remained rather challenging because certain external factors, like temperature, solubility, molecularity, solvent systems, pH values, crystallization processes, etc., have a profound effect on the final structure of the CPs. On the other hand, a judicious variation of these factors can produce different isomeric CPs from the same reactants. The isolation of different isomers is very important as they provide an unparalleled means for the understanding of structure-property relationships. A notable example is the isolation of cis-platin, cis-[Pt(NH3)2C12], which is widely used in cancer chemotherapy, whereas trans-platin exhibits no antitumor activity at all. However, to perceive the isomeric effect, most of the work has been done with discrete mono- or polynuclear species; not much work is reported on isomerism of coordination polymers and on the differences in their properties.

elements.content: Coordination polymers have recently surfaced as an important class of materials to have conductive properties and find applications in Schottky diodes and photosensing devices. However, fabrication of electronic devices with CPs is still a challenge because they are hybrid materials (composed of organic ligands and inorganic metal ions). The redox inactive organic ligands have very low conductivity, which results in overall lowering of conductivity of the species. Nevertheless, with the proper selection of the components, CPs can be branded as device applicable materials. The presence of extended π-conjugation in the organic ligands and π···π stacking interactions between highly conjugated electron rich aromatic moieties enhances the charge mobility in CPs. Hence, the use of dicarboxylates as “linkers” to join the organic nodes in the construction of CPs make them efficiently sensitive to external stimuli. Moreover, it has been found that CPs with metal ions having d10 configuration (e.g., Zn­(II), Cd­(II), etc.) are highly conductive and show interesting photochemical and photophysical properties, presumably due to their flexible nature and ability to produce different molecular geometries with severe distortions. It has been noted that both structural stability and thermodynamic stability make an impact on their electrical properties. Relatively strong covalent bonding among nodes and linkers provides higher stability and increases the effective efficiency in optoelectronic fields. Recently, it has been reported that structural transformations by the photodimerization reaction have significant impacts on the electrical conductivity of the species, but until now, there has been no report on how geometrical isomerism (cis–trans) in CPs can affect the electronic properties of the complexes.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers have recently surfaced as an important class of materials to have conductive properties and find applications in Schottky diodes and photosensing devices. However, fabrication of electronic devices with CPs is still a challenge because they are hybrid materials (composed of organic ligands and inorganic metal ions). The redox inactive organic ligands have very low conductivity, which results in overall lowering of conductivity of the species. Nevertheless, with the proper selection of the components, CPs can be branded as device applicable materials. The presence of extended π-conjugation in the organic ligands and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between highly conjugated electron rich aromatic moieties enhances the charge mobility in CPs. Hence, the use of dicarboxylates as "linkers" to join the organic nodes in the construction of CPs make them efficiently sensitive to external stimuli. Moreover, it has been found that CPs with metal ions having d10 configuration (e.g., Zn(II), Cd(II), etc.) are highly conductive and show interesting photochemical and photophysical properties, presumably due to their flexible nature and ability to produce different molecular geometries with severe distortions. It has been noted that both structural stability and thermodynamic stability make an impact on their electrical properties. Relatively strong covalent bonding among nodes and linkers provides higher stability and increases the effective efficiency in optoelectronic fields. Recently, it has been reported that structural transformations by the photodimerization reaction have significant impacts on the electrical conductivity of the species, but until now, there has been no report on how geometrical isomerism (cis-trans) in CPs can affect the electronic properties of the complexes.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis of two new isomeric 1D coordination polymers (1 and 2) obtained by varying the solvent of the synthesis, having formula unit {[(CuL1)2CdL2]·H2O} n , in which the carboxylate ligands [L2]2– are coordinated to Cd­(II) in cis (1) or trans (2) fashion. Impedance, capacitance, and current–voltage (I–V) studies have been done in order to perceive and draw a proper comparison between the electrical properties of the two isomers. The electrical conductivity and photosensitivity of 2 is found to be appreciably higher than 1. The energetic difference of the two complexes was also studied by DFT calculations. Thus, the differences between two isomeric CPs in regard to their thermodynamic stability and electrical properties have been discussed.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis of two new isomeric 1D coordination polymers (1 and 2) obtained by varying the solvent of the synthesis, having formula unit {[(CuL1)2CdL2]⋅H2O} n , in which the carboxylate ligands [L2]2- are coordinated to Cd(II) in cis (1) or trans (2) fashion. Impedance, capacitance, and current-voltage (I-V) studies have been done in order to perceive and draw a proper comparison between the electrical properties of the two isomers. The electrical conductivity and photosensitivity of 2 is found to be appreciably higher than 1. The energetic difference of the two complexes was also studied by DFT calculations. Thus, the differences between two isomeric CPs in regard to their thermodynamic stability and electrical properties have been discussed.

elements.content: 2-Hydroxyacetophenone and 1,3-propanediamine were purchased from Spectrochem, and biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid was from Sigma-Aldrich. All the chemicals were commercially available and were of reagent grade. They were used for reactions without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Starting Materials

2-Hydroxyacetophenone and 1,3-propanediamine were purchased from Spectrochem, and biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid was from Sigma-Aldrich. All the chemicals were commercially available and were of reagent grade. They were used for reactions without further purification.

elements.content: Caution! Although not encountered during the experiment, perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.
elements.clean_text: Caution! Although not encountered during the experiment, perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.

elements.content: The Schiff base ligand (H2L1) was prepared following previously described methods. The metalloligand (CuL1) was also prepared according to the reported methods as written briefly here. To a methanolic solution (10 mL) of ligand (H2L1) (5 mmol), a methanolic solution of Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol, 10 mL) was added. To this mixture, triethylamine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was slowly added. The solution was kept in a beaker for slow evaporation of the solvent. A dark brown crystalline solid product of the precursor [CuL1] complex was isolated after 2 days by filtration.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Schiff Base Ligand (H2L1) and the "Metalloligand" (CuL1)

The Schiff base ligand (H2L1) was prepared following previously described methods. The metalloligand (CuL1) was also prepared according to the reported methods as written briefly here. To a methanolic solution (10 mL) of ligand (H2L1) (5 mmol), a methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol, 10 mL) was added. To this mixture, triethylamine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was slowly added. The solution was kept in a beaker for slow evaporation of the solvent. A dark brown crystalline solid product of the precursor [CuL1] complex was isolated after 2 days by filtration.

elements.content: A 10 mL methanolic solution of the metalloligand [CuL1] (0.772 g, 2 mmol) was prepared, and a 5 mL methanolic solution of Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.330 g, 1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred well for 5 min for proper mixing. A 10 mL aqueous solution of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2L2) was prepared (0.242 g, 1 mmol) separately. To deprotonate the acid, triethylamine (276 μL, 2 mmol) was slowly added and mixed well. The aqueous deprotonated acid solution, [L2]2–, was filtered, and the clear solution was poured in a layer tube. The green methanolic solution of the heterometallic [Cu­(II)–Cd­(II)] complex was layered very carefully on it. The layered solution was then left undisturbed. After a week, reddish green X-ray quality crystals were obtained at the junction of the two solutions in the tube.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complex cis-{[(CuL1)2CdL2]⋅H2O} n  (1)

A 10 mL methanolic solution of the metalloligand [CuL1] (0.772 g, 2 mmol) was prepared, and a 5 mL methanolic solution of Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.330 g, 1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred well for 5 min for proper mixing. A 10 mL aqueous solution of biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2L2) was prepared (0.242 g, 1 mmol) separately. To deprotonate the acid, triethylamine (276 μL, 2 mmol) was slowly added and mixed well. The aqueous deprotonated acid solution, [L2]2-, was filtered, and the clear solution was poured in a layer tube. The green methanolic solution of the heterometallic [Cu(II)-Cd(II)] complex was layered very carefully on it. The layered solution was then left undisturbed. After a week, reddish green X-ray quality crystals were obtained at the junction of the two solutions in the tube.

elements.content: Yield 0.812 g (72%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H48CdCu2N4O10 (1128.42). Calculated: C, 55.35; H, 4.29; N, 4.96; found: C, 55.40; H, 4.30; N, 5.02. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO–) = 1580, 1384 cm–1, ν­(C = N) = 1598 cm–1.

elements.content: Complex 2 was synthesized in a similar method to that of complex 1 except that the solution of metalloligand and Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O was prepared in acetone instead of methanol. Green colored single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained at the junction of two solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complex trans-{[(CuL1)2CdL2]⋅H2O} n  (2)

Complex 2 was synthesized in a similar method to that of complex 1 except that the solution of metalloligand and Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O was prepared in acetone instead of methanol. Green colored single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained at the junction of two solutions.

elements.clean_text:
Complex 2 

Yield 0.736 g (65%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H52CdCu2N4O10 (1132.45). Calculated: C, 55.15; H, 4.63; N, 4.95; found: C, 55.23; H, 4.61; N, 4.75. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO-) = 1583, 1383 cm-1, ν(C = N) = 1599 cm-1.

elements.content: The Schiff base ligand, H2L1, was prepared by 1:2 condensation of 1,3-propanediamine with 2-hydroxyacetophenone in methanol following the reported method. This ligand was then mixed with a methanolic solution of Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O in equal proportions to prepare the precursor metalloligand [CuL1]. It was used for the preparation of complexes 1 and 2. Complex 1 was synthesized by layering a methanolic solution of the CuL1–Cd mixture of 2:1 molar ratio with an aqueous solution of the linker (H2L2) in a ratio of 1:1 with the Cu­(II)–Cd­(II) mixture. Reddish green, needle shaped crystals of complex 1 appeared at the junction of the two solutions after a few days. For complex 2, the same procedure was repeated, except for using an acetone solution of the resulting Cu–Cd mixture instead of a methanolic solution of the mixture. Block shaped light green colored crystals appeared at the junction of the two solutions after a week. The color and shape of the crystals of the two complexes were different, and their X-ray analyses clearly show that they are isomeric products. Absorption spectra of both complexes in methanol solvent were also measured as shown in Figure S2. The preparation of complexes 1 and 2 from metalloligand CuL1 is shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of the Complexes

The Schiff base ligand, H2L1, was prepared by 1:2 condensation of 1,3-propanediamine with 2-hydroxyacetophenone in methanol following the reported method. This ligand was then mixed with a methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in equal proportions to prepare the precursor metalloligand [CuL1]. It was used for the preparation of complexes 1 and 2. Complex 1 was synthesized by layering a methanolic solution of the CuL1-Cd mixture of 2:1 molar ratio with an aqueous solution of the linker (H2L2) in a ratio of 1:1 with the Cu(II)-Cd(II) mixture. Reddish green, needle shaped crystals of complex 1 appeared at the junction of the two solutions after a few days. For complex 2, the same procedure was repeated, except for using an acetone solution of the resulting Cu-Cd mixture instead of a methanolic solution of the mixture. Block shaped light green colored crystals appeared at the junction of the two solutions after a week. The color and shape of the crystals of the two complexes were different, and their X-ray analyses clearly show that they are isomeric products. Absorption spectra of both complexes in methanol solvent were also measured as shown in Figure S2. The preparation of complexes 1 and 2 from metalloligand CuL1 is shown in .

elements.content: The IR spectra of complexes 1 and 2 were measured by the FT-IR technique on KBr pellets. FT-IR on KBr pellets showed characteristic stretching vibrations for the azomethine (CN) group around 1598 cm–1 for both the complexes. Two sharp peaks at 1580 and 1384 cm–1 appear for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of −COO̅, respectively, in these complexes. The IR spectral data for both the complexes are given in Figures S3 and S4.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra of Complexes 1 and 2 

The IR spectra of complexes 1 and 2 were measured by the FT-IR technique on KBr pellets. FT-IR on KBr pellets showed characteristic stretching vibrations for the azomethine (CN) group around 1598 cm-1 for both the complexes. Two sharp peaks at 1580 and 1384 cm-1 appear for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of -COO̅, respectively, in these complexes. The IR spectral data for both the complexes are given in Figures S3 and S4.

elements.content: shows the essential features of the structure of 1; CdL2 (CuL1)2 is formed around the 2-fold axis, which passes through the Cd atom. The Cd atom is bonded to two ligands [L2]2– via O5 of the carboxyl group at 2.190(7) Å. Each of these ligands [L2]2– bridge to another Cd atom as shown in , thus forming a one-dimensional polymer. In addition, the Cd atom is bonded to two sets of O1, O2 atoms from [L1]2– making up a distorted octahedral environment. These two oxygen atoms form bridges to the Cu atom, which in addition is bonded to two nitrogen atoms N1, N2 of [L1]2– in a square planar environment. In the basal plane, Cu–O distances are 1.910(6) and 1.895(6) Å and Cu–N distances are 1.975(10) and 1.952(9) Å. The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviation of the four basally coordinated atoms of Cu1 from the mean plane is 0.172 Å with the copper atom at 0.021(4) Å from the least-squares equatorial plane of the four donor atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Structures

  shows the essential features of the structure of 1; CdL2 (CuL1)2 is formed around the 2-fold axis, which passes through the Cd atom. The Cd atom is bonded to two ligands [L2]2- via O5 of the carboxyl group at 2.190(7) Å. Each of these ligands [L2]2- bridge to another Cd atom as shown in , thus forming a one-dimensional polymer. In addition, the Cd atom is bonded to two sets of O1, O2 atoms from [L1]2- making up a distorted octahedral environment. These two oxygen atoms form bridges to the Cu atom, which in addition is bonded to two nitrogen atoms N1, N2 of [L1]2- in a square planar environment. In the basal plane, Cu-O distances are 1.910(6) and 1.895(6) Å and Cu-N distances are 1.975(10) and 1.952(9) Å. The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviation of the four basally coordinated atoms of Cu1 from the mean plane is 0.172 Å with the copper atom at 0.021(4) Å from the least-squares equatorial plane of the four donor atoms.

elements.content: Structure of complex 1, in which the crystallographic 2-fold axis passes through the Cd atom. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of complex 1, in which the crystallographic 2-fold axis passes through the Cd atom. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Structure of 1 showing the formation of the one-dimensional polymer. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of 1 showing the formation of the one-dimensional polymer. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The structure of 2, also CdL2 (CuL1)2, is shown in . Both metals are in special positions, Cd1 in a 2/m site and Cu1 in an m site. In contrast with complex 1, here, the carboxylate of the bridging ligand is bonded to both metals, O1 to Cd1 at 2.233(10) Å and O3 to Cu1 at 2.214(10) Å, as shown in . Also unlike 1, the two bridging carboxyl O1 atoms are mutually trans rather than cis. The Cd atom is six-coordinate with a disordered octahedral environment being bonded to two carboxylate oxygen atoms and four equivalent oxygen atoms of two ligands, [L1]2–. Unlike in 1, each equivalent copper atom is five-coordinate, being bonded to the four donor atoms of the ligand (O11, O11a and N19, N19a) together with an oxygen atom O3 of the carboxylic acid group (where the superscript “a” denotes the symmetry transformation x, −y, z). This latter oxygen atom is in an axial position. The Cu1–O11 and Cu1–N19 distances are 1.951(6) and 1.994(8) Å, respectively. A plane of symmetry is present on the Cu1 atom, which is why the trans angles are equal and hence the calculated Addison parameter (τ5) is 0 (τ5 = (β – α)/60). The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviation of the four basally coordinated atoms of Cu1 from the mean plane is therefore 0.000 Å, with the copper atom 0.186(6) Å away from the plane in the direction of the axial O3 atom. Details of the crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Table S2.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 2, also CdL2 (CuL1)2, is shown in . Both metals are in special positions, Cd1 in a 2/m site and Cu1 in an m site. In contrast with complex 1, here, the carboxylate of the bridging ligand is bonded to both metals, O1 to Cd1 at 2.233(10) Å and O3 to Cu1 at 2.214(10) Å, as shown in . Also unlike 1, the two bridging carboxyl O1 atoms are mutually trans rather than cis. The Cd atom is six-coordinate with a disordered octahedral environment being bonded to two carboxylate oxygen atoms and four equivalent oxygen atoms of two ligands, [L1]2-. Unlike in 1, each equivalent copper atom is five-coordinate, being bonded to the four donor atoms of the ligand (O11, O11a and N19, N19a) together with an oxygen atom O3 of the carboxylic acid group (where the superscript "a" denotes the symmetry transformation x, -y, z). This latter oxygen atom is in an axial position. The Cu1-O11 and Cu1-N19 distances are 1.951(6) and 1.994(8) Å, respectively. A plane of symmetry is present on the Cu1 atom, which is why the trans angles are equal and hence the calculated Addison parameter (τ5) is 0 (τ5 = (β - α)/60). The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviation of the four basally coordinated atoms of Cu1 from the mean plane is therefore 0.000 Å, with the copper atom 0.186(6) Å away from the plane in the direction of the axial O3 atom. Details of the crystallographic data are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Table S2.

elements.content: Both the complexes 1 and 2 are one-dimensional coordination polymers in which the trinuclear nodes [(CuL1)2Cd] are linked by biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid. However, significant differences are found between 1 and 2 in the propagation of the chain. In complex 1, two oxygen atoms, one each from two acids, bind the central Cd­(II) atom in a cis configuration resulting in a zigzag 1D chain, while in 2, the dicarboxylate linker joins the neighboring trinuclear units, coordinating to both Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) metal atoms through syn–syn bridging mode. Unlike 1, here, the two oxygen atoms of carboxylate linker are trans coordinated to Cd, and as a result, the 1D chain is linear as shown in . It is to be noted that, although no solvent molecule is present in either structure, their formation is dependent on the solvent used for their synthesis. The more polar solvent methanol stabilizes the cis isomer (1), whereas the less polar acetone yields the trans form (2). When a (1:1) mixture of methanol and acetone was used as solvent, a mixture of cis and trans isomers was isolated. Isolation of both the cis and trans isomers indicates the presence of both in an equilibrium in the solution, where the relative concentration/solubility of a particular isomer governs the identity of the species that crystallizes from the corresponding solution.
elements.clean_text: Both the complexes 1 and 2 are one-dimensional coordination polymers in which the trinuclear nodes [(CuL1)2Cd] are linked by biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid. However, significant differences are found between 1 and 2 in the propagation of the chain. In complex 1, two oxygen atoms, one each from two acids, bind the central Cd(II) atom in a cis configuration resulting in a zigzag 1D chain, while in 2, the dicarboxylate linker joins the neighboring trinuclear units, coordinating to both Cu(II) and Cd(II) metal atoms through syn-syn bridging mode. Unlike 1, here, the two oxygen atoms of carboxylate linker are trans coordinated to Cd, and as a result, the 1D chain is linear as shown in . It is to be noted that, although no solvent molecule is present in either structure, their formation is dependent on the solvent used for their synthesis. The more polar solvent methanol stabilizes the cis isomer (1), whereas the less polar acetone yields the trans form (2). When a (1:1) mixture of methanol and acetone was used as solvent, a mixture of cis and trans isomers was isolated. Isolation of both the cis and trans isomers indicates the presence of both in an equilibrium in the solution, where the relative concentration/solubility of a particular isomer governs the identity of the species that crystallizes from the corresponding solution.

elements.content: First of all, we have analyzed the energetic difference between both binding modes observed for the metalloligands and biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands around Cd­(II). In complex 1, the carboxylate groups are monodentate and connected only to the Cd­(II) metal center. In contrast, in complex 2, they are bidentate and bridge the Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) metal centers, as previously discussed in the experimental description. In , we show the fully optimized complexes that we have obtained starting from the crystallographic coordinates and replacing the biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands with formate. The coordination distances are in quite good agreement with the experimental ones. In the gas phase, complex 2 is considerably more stable than 1 (18.5 kcal/mol). The addition of the dispersion correction to the calculation decreases the difference from 18.5 to 12.9 kcal/mol. Furthermore, the addition of solvent effects decreases the difference to 4.3 kcal/mol in MeOH and 4.8 kcal/mol in acetone. Complex 2 is likely more stable than 1 due to the additional O···Cu coordination bonds involving the biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands. However, the difference in solution (4.3/4.8 kcal/mol) can be easily compensated in the solid state by packing effects and noncovalent interactions. It is also worth mentioning that solvent effects are taken into consideration by using a continuum model (COSMO) that basically uses the dielectric constant of the solvent. Both solvents present quite similar dielectric constants (32.7 and 20.7 for MeOH and acetone, respectively), and consequently, the computed relative energies shown in a are also similar. However, the main difference between both solvents is that MeOH is protic and, consequently, it is a good H-bond donor. This aspect is not considered by the COSMO method, but it is likely crucial in the stabilization of the complexes, specially taking into account that they have a large number of H-bond acceptor sites.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

First of all, we have analyzed the energetic difference between both binding modes observed for the metalloligands and biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands around Cd(II). In complex 1, the carboxylate groups are monodentate and connected only to the Cd(II) metal center. In contrast, in complex 2, they are bidentate and bridge the Cu(II) and Cd(II) metal centers, as previously discussed in the experimental description. In , we show the fully optimized complexes that we have obtained starting from the crystallographic coordinates and replacing the biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands with formate. The coordination distances are in quite good agreement with the experimental ones. In the gas phase, complex 2 is considerably more stable than 1 (18.5 kcal/mol). The addition of the dispersion correction to the calculation decreases the difference from 18.5 to 12.9 kcal/mol. Furthermore, the addition of solvent effects decreases the difference to 4.3 kcal/mol in MeOH and 4.8 kcal/mol in acetone. Complex 2 is likely more stable than 1 due to the additional O⋅⋅⋅Cu coordination bonds involving the biphenyl-dicarboxylate ligands. However, the difference in solution (4.3/4.8 kcal/mol) can be easily compensated in the solid state by packing effects and noncovalent interactions. It is also worth mentioning that solvent effects are taken into consideration by using a continuum model (COSMO) that basically uses the dielectric constant of the solvent. Both solvents present quite similar dielectric constants (32.7 and 20.7 for MeOH and acetone, respectively), and consequently, the computed relative energies shown in a are also similar. However, the main difference between both solvents is that MeOH is protic and, consequently, it is a good H-bond donor. This aspect is not considered by the COSMO method, but it is likely crucial in the stabilization of the complexes, specially taking into account that they have a large number of H-bond acceptor sites.

elements.content: B3LYP/def2-SVP optimized complexes and relative energies of the theoretical models of complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b).
elements.clean_text: 5  B3LYP/def2-SVP optimized complexes and relative energies of the theoretical models of complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b).

elements.content: We have also analyzed the π-stacking and C–H···π interactions involving the phenyl ring and the six-membered CuOCCCN chelate ring observed in the solid state architecture of complexes 1 and 2, respectively. First of all, we have studied energetically the π–π interaction in complex 1 (see ) that is established between the π-clouds of the aromatic (orange colored) and chelate rings (blue colored) and characterized by a short centroid to centroid distance (3.56 Å; see b). It has been recently proposed that chelate ring···chelate ring (CR···CR) and chelate ring···arene (CR···π) interactions are energetically stronger than conventional π-stacking interactions. As represented in a, complex 1 forms zigzag polymeric chains that interact with each other by means of two symmetrically equivalent chelate ring···π (CR···π) interactions. By using a minimalistic model where only the metalloligands are considered, we have evaluated energetically the self-assembled dimer shown in b. The binding energy is very large ΔE 1 = −24.3 kcal/mol and comparable to other π-assemblies involving chelate rings. This result confirms the strong nature of this type of noncovalent interaction. We have also computed the “non-covalent interaction plot” (NCI plot) index in order to characterize the interaction in 1. The NCI plot is an intuitive visualization index that enables the identification of noncovalent interactions easily and efficiently. The NCI plot is convenient to analyze host–guest interactions, since it clearly shows which molecular regions interact. The color scheme is a red–yellow–green–blue scale with red being repulsive and blue being attractive. Yellow and green surfaces correspond to weak repulsive and weak attractive interactions, respectively. The representation of the NCI plot is shown in c. As noted, an extended isosurface between both aromatic and chelate rings confirms the π–π interaction. The isosurface clearly extends to the chelate ring, thus confirming the CR···π interaction.
elements.clean_text: We have also analyzed the π-stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving the phenyl ring and the six-membered CuOCCCN chelate ring observed in the solid state architecture of complexes 1 and 2, respectively. First of all, we have studied energetically the π-π interaction in complex 1 (see ) that is established between the π-clouds of the aromatic (orange colored) and chelate rings (blue colored) and characterized by a short centroid to centroid distance (3.56 Å; see b). It has been recently proposed that chelate ring⋅⋅⋅chelate ring (CR⋅⋅⋅CR) and chelate ring⋅⋅⋅arene (CR⋅⋅⋅π) interactions are energetically stronger than conventional π-stacking interactions. As represented in a, complex 1 forms zigzag polymeric chains that interact with each other by means of two symmetrically equivalent chelate ring⋅⋅⋅π (CR⋅⋅⋅π) interactions. By using a minimalistic model where only the metalloligands are considered, we have evaluated energetically the self-assembled dimer shown in b. The binding energy is very large ΔE 1 = -24.3 kcal/mol and comparable to other π-assemblies involving chelate rings. This result confirms the strong nature of this type of noncovalent interaction. We have also computed the "non-covalent interaction plot" (NCI plot) index in order to characterize the interaction in 1. The NCI plot is an intuitive visualization index that enables the identification of noncovalent interactions easily and efficiently. The NCI plot is convenient to analyze host-guest interactions, since it clearly shows which molecular regions interact. The color scheme is a red-yellow-green-blue scale with red being repulsive and blue being attractive. Yellow and green surfaces correspond to weak repulsive and weak attractive interactions, respectively. The representation of the NCI plot is shown in c. As noted, an extended isosurface between both aromatic and chelate rings confirms the π-π interaction. The isosurface clearly extends to the chelate ring, thus confirming the CR⋅⋅⋅π interaction.

elements.content: (a) Partial view of the X-ray structure of complex 1. (b) Theoretical model used to evaluate the π-stacking interaction. (c) NCI surface of the model of complex 1. The gradient cutoff is s = 0.35 au, and the color scale is −0.04 < ρ < 0.04 au.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Partial view of the X-ray structure of complex 1. (b) Theoretical model used to evaluate the π-stacking interaction. (c) NCI surface of the model of complex 1. The gradient cutoff is s = 0.35 au, and the color scale is -0.04 < ρ < 0.04 au.

elements.content: A partial view of the X-ray structure of 2 is shown in a. In this complex, the polymeric chain is linear and interacts with the adjacent chain by means of two types of C–H···π interactions as shown in c. That is, the six-membered chelate ring interacts with the methyl group of the Schiff-base ligand and the phenyl ring, with one methylene group of the propylene linker that connects both imido groups. We have computed the molecular electrostatic potential (MEP) plotted onto the van der Waals surface in order to investigate the electron rich and electron poor parts of the metalloligand. It can be observed that the most positive region is located at the propylene linker and also the methyl group (+24 kcal/mol, blue color). In addition, both the aromatic and chelate rings exhibit negative potential over the ring centroids, thus being suitable for interacting with positive regions. Therefore, both C–H···π and C–H···π­(CR) are electrostatically favored. In fact, the interaction energy of the complex shown in b is large and negative, ΔE 2 = −18.1 kcal/mol, in agreement with the MEP analysis. We have also computed the NCI plot index in order to characterize the C–H···π and C–H···π­(CR) interactions in the dimer of 2 (see d). Both interactions are characterized by extended green isosurfaces, which are located between the phenyl/chelate rings and the H atoms of the methyl/methylene groups, thus confirming the existence of both interactions.
elements.clean_text: A partial view of the X-ray structure of 2 is shown in a. In this complex, the polymeric chain is linear and interacts with the adjacent chain by means of two types of C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions as shown in c. That is, the six-membered chelate ring interacts with the methyl group of the Schiff-base ligand and the phenyl ring, with one methylene group of the propylene linker that connects both imido groups. We have computed the molecular electrostatic potential (MEP) plotted onto the van der Waals surface in order to investigate the electron rich and electron poor parts of the metalloligand. It can be observed that the most positive region is located at the propylene linker and also the methyl group (+24 kcal/mol, blue color). In addition, both the aromatic and chelate rings exhibit negative potential over the ring centroids, thus being suitable for interacting with positive regions. Therefore, both C-H⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π(CR) are electrostatically favored. In fact, the interaction energy of the complex shown in b is large and negative, ΔE 2 = -18.1 kcal/mol, in agreement with the MEP analysis. We have also computed the NCI plot index in order to characterize the C-H⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π(CR) interactions in the dimer of 2 (see d). Both interactions are characterized by extended green isosurfaces, which are located between the phenyl/chelate rings and the H atoms of the methyl/methylene groups, thus confirming the existence of both interactions.

elements.content: The current–voltage (I–V) characteristics of the systems with cis and trans isomers are depicted in . From the figure, it is apparent that, for a fixed voltage, the conductivity of the system with the trans isomer is larger than that of the cis isomer. At a fixed voltage of 1 V, the value of current conducted by the cis system is obtained to be 12.4 μA and that of the trans system is observed to be 21.0 μA. Relevant values for the current are obtained at 36.1 and 58.6 μA for 3 V and 63.1 and 101.0 μA for 5 V for cis and trans systems, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Characterization and Photosensitivity

The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of the systems with cis and trans isomers are depicted in . From the figure, it is apparent that, for a fixed voltage, the conductivity of the system with the trans isomer is larger than that of the cis isomer. At a fixed voltage of 1 V, the value of current conducted by the cis system is obtained to be 12.4 μA and that of the trans system is observed to be 21.0 μA. Relevant values for the current are obtained at 36.1 and 58.6 μA for 3 V and 63.1 and 101.0 μA for 5 V for cis and trans systems, respectively.

elements.content: Current–voltage (I–V) characteristics for the systems with cis and trans isomers.
elements.clean_text: 8  Current-voltage (I-V) characteristics for the systems with cis and trans isomers.

elements.content: shows the frequency spectrum of impedance and capacitance for the systems under investigation. The plots reveal that the impedance and capacitance values are greater for the cis system compared to the trans case, which is in agreement with the trend obtained from I–V characteristics. The impedance values for the system with the cis isomer vary from 51.03 to 5.14 KΩ for the frequency range of 1 kHz to 1 MHz. Relevant values for the systems with trans isomers are observed to vary from 27.29 to 2.7 KΩ. Similarly, the capacitance values are observed to vary from 234 to 34.2 pF and 146 to 29.9 pF for cis and trans isomers, respectively. For a fixed frequency of 10 kHz, the impedance values for cis and trans isomers are observed to be 50.1 and 26.8 KΩ, respectively. Similar values of capacitance for cis and trans isomers are 48.2 and 37.1 pF.

Similarly, the capacitance values are observed to vary from 234 to 34.2 pF and 146 to 29.9 pF for cis and trans isomers, respectively. For a fixed frequency of 10 kHz, the impedance values for cis and trans isomers are observed to be 50.1 and 26.8 KΩ, respectively. Similar values of capacitance for cis and trans isomers are 48.2 and 37.1 pF.

elements.content: Nyquist plots for the systems are depicted in , where real part of impedance is plotted against its imaginary part. It is apparent from the figures that the charge transfer resistance is higher for the systems with cis isomers in comparison with the trans case, which is again in agreement with the previous results.

elements.content: From , , and , it is clear that the conductivity for the system with the trans isomer (complex 2) is higher than that with the cis isomer (complex 1). This is attributed to the availability of free charges in the system with cis and trans isomers. In the case of cis isomer, [L2]2– binds the central metal ion using either of two oxygen atoms from the carboxylate group in a η1 fashion, thus having free carboxylic oxygen. However, it is absent in the trans isomer since both oxygen atoms from the linker bind the metal ions in a η2 manner. In the trans isomer, the additional O···Cu coordination bonds of the linker with the node increases the covalent contacts, which work as pavement during charge transport. Hence, in the case of 1, a charge trapping site is available in contrast to 2, which reduces the number of free charges in the system, thereby lowering the effective conductivity of it. This in turn increases the resultant resistance of the system. Also, the ability to store charge leads to a higher capacitance for the system with the cis isomer compared to the trans case. As a consequence, impedance, which is a complex quantity comprised of resistance and capacitive reactance, effectively gets lowered for complex 2 in comparison to complex 1.
elements.clean_text: From , , and , it is clear that the conductivity for the system with the trans isomer (complex 2) is higher than that with the cis isomer (complex 1). This is attributed to the availability of free charges in the system with cis and trans isomers. In the case of cis isomer, [L2]2- binds the central metal ion using either of two oxygen atoms from the carboxylate group in a η1 fashion, thus having free carboxylic oxygen. However, it is absent in the trans isomer since both oxygen atoms from the linker bind the metal ions in a η2 manner. In the trans isomer, the additional O⋅⋅⋅Cu coordination bonds of the linker with the node increases the covalent contacts, which work as pavement during charge transport. Hence, in the case of 1, a charge trapping site is available in contrast to 2, which reduces the number of free charges in the system, thereby lowering the effective conductivity of it. This in turn increases the resultant resistance of the system. Also, the ability to store charge leads to a higher capacitance for the system with the cis isomer compared to the trans case. As a consequence, impedance, which is a complex quantity comprised of resistance and capacitive reactance, effectively gets lowered for complex 2 in comparison to complex 1.

elements.content: A thorough survey reveals that the electrical conductivity of a coordination polymer/MOF is known to vary with the extent of conjugation, length, or number of donor sites of the linker for a particular node. The mobility of charge through aromatic dicarboxylates, azo bridged or pyridine-based N–donor linkers, is found to be considerably different. However, to our knowledge, this is the first study of the electrical conductivity of two geometrical isomers (cis–trans) of a complex. In these two isomers, the difference in electrical conductivity can only be attributed to the crucial change in the coordination/binding mode of the dicarboxylate linker.
elements.clean_text: A thorough survey reveals that the electrical conductivity of a coordination polymer/MOF is known to vary with the extent of conjugation, length, or number of donor sites of the linker for a particular node. The mobility of charge through aromatic dicarboxylates, azo bridged or pyridine-based N-donor linkers, is found to be considerably different. However, to our knowledge, this is the first study of the electrical conductivity of two geometrical isomers (cis-trans) of a complex. In these two isomers, the difference in electrical conductivity can only be attributed to the crucial change in the coordination/binding mode of the dicarboxylate linker.

elements.content: indicates the photoresponsive behavior of the fabricated complexes when exposed to light. It is seen that the conductivity values of both the complexes change noticeably under dark and light conditions, although complex 2 is arguably much more responsive than 1. As the materials exhibit photosensitivity, the electric current of the materials was measured many times at a constant bias voltage of 2 V by switching the light on and off repeatedly at a definite time interval of 25 s as shown in . The corresponding results reveal that the materials have good sensitivity to the light source, which can be switched many times repeatedly without deterioration of the on/off ratio. The 1D polymeric chains behave as molecular antenna to receive photons under illumination and energize the charge carriers. As a result, the mobility of charge carriers is increased, which leads to the enhancement of the conductivity. Moreover, the organic ligand being rich in π-electrons may behave as an electron donor on photoexcitation, while the inorganic part (Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) metal centers) will act as an electron acceptor.
elements.clean_text:
Photosensitive Study

  indicates the photoresponsive behavior of the fabricated complexes when exposed to light. It is seen that the conductivity values of both the complexes change noticeably under dark and light conditions, although complex 2 is arguably much more responsive than 1. As the materials exhibit photosensitivity, the electric current of the materials was measured many times at a constant bias voltage of 2 V by switching the light on and off repeatedly at a definite time interval of 25 s as shown in . The corresponding results reveal that the materials have good sensitivity to the light source, which can be switched many times repeatedly without deterioration of the on/off ratio. The 1D polymeric chains behave as molecular antenna to receive photons under illumination and energize the charge carriers. As a result, the mobility of charge carriers is increased, which leads to the enhancement of the conductivity. Moreover, the organic ligand being rich in π-electrons may behave as an electron donor on photoexcitation, while the inorganic part (Cu(II) and Cd(II) metal centers) will act as an electron acceptor.

elements.content: Comparative photocurrent response graph of cis and trans isomers (complexes 1 and 2, respectively) under dark and light conditions.
elements.clean_text: 11  Comparative photocurrent response graph of cis and trans isomers (complexes 1 and 2, respectively) under dark and light conditions.

elements.content: Transient photocurrent response curve of complexes 1 and 2, respectively, measured at an interval of 25 s.
elements.clean_text: 12  Transient photocurrent response curve of complexes 1 and 2, respectively, measured at an interval of 25 s.

elements.content: In accordance with the current–voltage (I–V) measurements reported earlier in this work, complex 2 acts as a better photoswitch than complex 1. The effective mobility (μeff) of the carriers under the dark was estimated at 1.66 × 10–7 m2V–1s–1 whereas it improves to 3.36 × 10–5 m2V–1s–1 after soaking in light; for 1 (cis), it is 8.00 × 10–7 m2V–1s–1, and for 2 (trans), it is 4.58 × 10–4 m2V–1s–1. The photosensitivity of the cis and trans isomers is 201.40 and 571.50, respectively, which can be determined from . The result reflects a lower recombination rate and a more efficient separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs for the complex 2-based device. This high photosensitivity is quite appreciable and assures an essential step toward the use of heterometallic coordination polymers in optoelectronics and photovoltaic cells.
elements.clean_text: In accordance with the current-voltage (I-V) measurements reported earlier in this work, complex 2 acts as a better photoswitch than complex 1. The effective mobility (μeff) of the carriers under the dark was estimated at 1.66 × 10-7 m2V-1s-1 whereas it improves to 3.36 × 10-5 m2V-1s-1 after soaking in light; for 1 (cis), it is 8.00 × 10-7 m2V-1s-1, and for 2 (trans), it is 4.58 × 10-4 m2V-1s-1. The photosensitivity of the cis and trans isomers is 201.40 and 571.50, respectively, which can be determined from . The result reflects a lower recombination rate and a more efficient separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs for the complex 2-based device. This high photosensitivity is quite appreciable and assures an essential step toward the use of heterometallic coordination polymers in optoelectronics and photovoltaic cells.

elements.content: In an attempt to join the trinuclear [(CuL1)2Cd] nodes of an N2O2 donor tetradentate Schiff base ligand with 4,4′-benzenedicarboxylate, here, we serendipitously isolated two isomeric 1D chains, 1 and 2, simply by changing the solvent used in the synthesis. Complex 1, which has a zigzag 1D chain structure, formed by the η1 coordination of carboxylate groups to Cd­(II) in cis configuration, is produced from methanol whereas acetone solvent yields a linear 1D chain (2), in which the trans-oriented η2 syn–syn bridging dicarboxylate links the nodes. By means of DFT calculations, we have compared both coordination modes observed for the metalloligands around the Cd­(II) metal center. Moreover, we have evaluated energetically the strength of the unconventional CR···π interactions in 1 and C–H···π/CR in 2. These energetically significant interactions are responsible for the interaction of the polymeric chains and are important in the crystal packing of both complexes. The differences in the mode of bridging and crystal packing of the two complexes have a significant impact on the electrical properties of these materials. Both complexes serve as good conductors of electricity and have the potential for photoswitching, but complex 2 is found to be a more promising material than 1. In a nutshell, our work on the design of isomeric coordination polymers with different thermodynamic stabilities, exhibiting different extents of electrical activity, is a promising step toward future scientific endeavors and the generation of smart electronic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In an attempt to join the trinuclear [(CuL1)2Cd] nodes of an N2O2 donor tetradentate Schiff base ligand with 4,4'-benzenedicarboxylate, here, we serendipitously isolated two isomeric 1D chains, 1 and 2, simply by changing the solvent used in the synthesis. Complex 1, which has a zigzag 1D chain structure, formed by the η1 coordination of carboxylate groups to Cd(II) in cis configuration, is produced from methanol whereas acetone solvent yields a linear 1D chain (2), in which the trans-oriented η2 syn-syn bridging dicarboxylate links the nodes. By means of DFT calculations, we have compared both coordination modes observed for the metalloligands around the Cd(II) metal center. Moreover, we have evaluated energetically the strength of the unconventional CR⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 1 and C-H⋅⋅⋅π/CR in 2. These energetically significant interactions are responsible for the interaction of the polymeric chains and are important in the crystal packing of both complexes. The differences in the mode of bridging and crystal packing of the two complexes have a significant impact on the electrical properties of these materials. Both complexes serve as good conductors of electricity and have the potential for photoswitching, but complex 2 is found to be a more promising material than 1. In a nutshell, our work on the design of isomeric coordination polymers with different thermodynamic stabilities, exhibiting different extents of electrical activity, is a promising step toward future scientific endeavors and the generation of smart electronic materials.

cln_elements.content:
The Schiff base ligand (H2L1) was prepared following previously described methods. The metalloligand (CuL1) was also prepared according to the reported methods as written briefly here. To a methanolic solution (10 mL) of ligand (H2L1) (5 mmol), a methanolic solution of Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol, 10 mL) was added. To this mixture, triethylamine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was slowly added. The solution was kept in a beaker for slow evaporation of the solvent. A dark brown crystalline solid product of the precursor [CuL1] complex was isolated after 2 days by filtration.

Synthesis of the Complex <italic>cis</italic>-{[(CuL<sup>1</sup>)<sub>2</sub>CdL<sup>2</sup>]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A 10 mL methanolic solution of the metalloligand [CuL1] (0.772 g, 2 mmol) was prepared, and a 5 mL methanolic solution of Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.330 g, 1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred well for 5 min for proper mixing. A 10 mL aqueous solution of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2L2) was prepared (0.242 g, 1 mmol) separately. To deprotonate the acid, triethylamine (276 μL, 2 mmol) was slowly added and mixed well. The aqueous deprotonated acid solution, [L2]2–, was filtered, and the clear solution was poured in a layer tube. The green methanolic solution of the heterometallic [Cu­(II)–Cd­(II)] complex was layered very carefully on it. The layered solution was then left undisturbed. After a week, reddish green X-ray quality crystals were obtained at the junction of the two solutions in the tube.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Schiff Base Ligand (H2L1) and the "Metalloligand" (CuL1)

The Schiff base ligand (H2L1) was prepared following previously described methods. The metalloligand (CuL1) was also prepared according to the reported methods as written briefly here. To a methanolic solution (10 mL) of ligand (H2L1) (5 mmol), a methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol, 10 mL) was added. To this mixture, triethylamine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was slowly added. The solution was kept in a beaker for slow evaporation of the solvent. A dark brown crystalline solid product of the precursor [CuL1] complex was isolated after 2 days by filtration.

Synthesis of the Complex cis-{[(CuL1)2CdL2]⋅H2O} n  (1)

A 10 mL methanolic solution of the metalloligand [CuL1] (0.772 g, 2 mmol) was prepared, and a 5 mL methanolic solution of Cd(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.330 g, 1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred well for 5 min for proper mixing. A 10 mL aqueous solution of biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2L2) was prepared (0.242 g, 1 mmol) separately. To deprotonate the acid, triethylamine (276 μL, 2 mmol) was slowly added and mixed well. The aqueous deprotonated acid solution, [L2]2-, was filtered, and the clear solution was poured in a layer tube. The green methanolic solution of the heterometallic [Cu(II)-Cd(II)] complex was layered very carefully on it. The layered solution was then left undisturbed. After a week, reddish green X-ray quality crystals were obtained at the junction of the two solutions in the tube.

cln_elements.content:
Yield 0.812 g (72%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H48CdCu2N4O10 (1128.42). Calculated: C, 55.35; H, 4.29; N, 4.96; found: C, 55.40; H, 4.30; N, 5.02. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO–) = 1580, 1384 cm–1, ν­(C = N) = 1598 cm–1.

Complex <bold>2</bold>

Yield 0.736 g (65%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H52CdCu2N4O10 (1132.45). Calculated: C, 55.15; H, 4.63; N, 4.95; found: C, 55.23; H, 4.61; N, 4.75. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO–) = 1583, 1383 cm–1, ν­(C = N) = 1599 cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Complex 1 

Yield 0.812 g (72%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H48CdCu2N4O10 (1128.42). Calculated: C, 55.35; H, 4.29; N, 4.96; found: C, 55.40; H, 4.30; N, 5.02. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO-) = 1580, 1384 cm-1, ν(C = N) = 1598 cm-1.

Complex 2 

Yield 0.736 g (65%) (with respect to CuL1). C52H52CdCu2N4O10 (1132.45). Calculated: C, 55.15; H, 4.63; N, 4.95; found: C, 55.23; H, 4.61; N, 4.75. IR (KBr): νs+as(COO-) = 1583, 1383 cm-1, ν(C = N) = 1599 cm-1.

metadata.title:
Two Geometrical Isomers of a 1D Coordination Polymer:
Rationalization by Theoretical Calculations and Variation of Electrical
Properties with the Change in Binding Mode of Dicarboxylate Linker
